About This Game

You are a gun for hire, trapped in a war-torn African state, stricken with malaria and forced to make deals with corrupt warlords on both sides of the conflict in order to make this country your home.
You must identify and exploit your enemies' weaknesses, neutralizing their superior numbers and firepower with surprise, subversion, cunning and of course brute force.
  • Fire Â Feel the heat of the most realistic fire ever seen in a video game! Use wind and propagation to surround and trap your enemies. Grab your Molotov cocktails or flamethrowers to take out your enemies.
  • Destructible environment Â No more obstacles: Everything is breakable and alterable, even in Multiplayer mode. The DUNIA engine's RealTree technology also delivers the most realistic nature deterioration system ever.
  • Open world Â Experience real freedom while roaming in more than 50km2 without any loading. Choose your own path in this vast environment and explore a living African world.
  • A huge adventure Â Fight for two rival factions, and make your way up to your primary target by any means necessary. Take on over 70 side missions to earn valuable information, new weapons and vehicles.
  • Non-scripted artificial intelligence Â Medics will drag wounded soldiers to safety. Grunts will come to fear you. Your reputation and in-game actions will make enemies drop their guns and run for their lives. Feel the tension of never knowing just how an enemy will react.
  • MULTIPLAYER Â Challenge your friends but watch your backÂyou never know who your true friends are and who might betray you! All the single player technical features are also present in multiplayer mode.
Far Cry 2: Fortune's Edition contains the full Far Cry 2 game, including all previously released patches and the Far Cry 2 Fortunes DLC with additional content listed below.

Single player additional content:
  • Three brand-new weapons: Silenced shotgun, Sawed-off shotgun, Crossbow
  • Two new vehicles: Unimog, Quad
Multiplayer additional content:
  • Additional weapons and four new exciting maps: Cheap Labor, Last Resort, Lake Smear, Fort Fury
READ MORE

System Requirements

    Minimum:
    • Supported OS: Microsoft Windows XP or Windows Vista (64 is supported)
    • Processor: Pentium 4 3.2 Ghz, Pentium D 2.66 Ghz, AMD Athlon 64 3500+ or better
    • Memory: 1 GB
    • Graphics: 256 MB, Shader Model 3 required, NVidia 6800 or ATI X1650 or better*
    • Hard Drive: 3.5 GB (Multiple saves and user created maps will increase the amount of needed hard disk space.)
    • *Supported Video cards: NVidia 6800, NVidia 7000 series, 8000 series, 9000 series, 200 series. 8800M and 8700M supported for laptops. ATI X1650 â 1950 series , HD2000 series , HD3000 series , HD4000 series
    Recommended:
    • Processor: Intel Core 2 Duo Family, AMD 64 X2 5200+, AMD Phenom or better
    • Memory: 2 GB RAM
    • Graphics: 512 MB, NVidia 8600 GTS or better, ATI X1900 or better*
    • Sound: 5.1 sound card recommended
READ MORE

96 of 107 people (90%) found this review helpful
2
Calvinic
302 products in account
34 reviews
Recommended
10.0 hrs on record
Posted: June 2
Far Cry 2 is game that I would call a "victim of the bandwagon". It was generally hated by the community upon release because it had nothing to do with the first game. (Which frankly isn't a bad thing.)

Rather, FC2 tried to take the series in a new direction. No mutants or cliche action seqences. Just gritty violent dark chaos unfolding in the African jungles around you. The stripped down approach is quite appealing because the game seems to take itself more seriously. Putting more emphasis on tactics than just going in guns blazing.

Story: You play as a hired gun that was sent by an unknown party to kill an infamous arms dealer named the Jackal. According to information provided, he is largely responsible for increasing instability inside Africa by stirring up civil wars in the country by providing weapons to both sides. Sounds easy, right? Go to Africa, find the Jackal, kill him. As you soon find out, it's not the simple. You soon start to play a part in the fate of the country and that perhaps, there's bigger problems than a person selling guns.

It's an interesting story if you're willing to invest into it. The Jackal is an interesting character to listen to as he describes his life in the country. How the increased violence and warfare is slowly tearing the country apart.

Gameplay: FC2 is a sandbox shooter at it's core. You're dropped into a beautiful lush world with various objectives to complete at your leisure. How you approach the goals is also up to you. Go guns blazing, go stealth, snipe, etc. As long as you got the tools, you got a plan. It's very satisfying to go in stealth and pick off guys from the darkness of the jungles. Watching them panic as their numbers get reduced one by one.

Overall, I can't complain about FC2. It's a well made shooter that will keep gamers entertained for while. If you like planning attacks out and you're all about think first, shoot later. This game is up your alley.

Posted: June 8
Brutal game. Just straight up cruel. Malaria. Guns that jam. Supplies are scarce. The hostile African landscape is crawling with soldiers who want you dead. A civil war fueled by powerhungry warmongers and funded by conflict diamonds that refuses to end, and an arms dealer at the center of this twisted web: The Jackal. Find him. Kill him.

This game gave me a Heart of Darkness.
10/10


God, I love the smell of napalm in the morning.

leadrhythmslide
87 products in account
5 reviews
Recommended
10.1 hrs on record
Posted: July 5
My Jeep had smoke coming out of the hood. It was driving slower than it usually did. I had just survived a brief skirmish with some trigger-happy hooligans, but with one quick grenade under their Jeep, the problem was solved. I saw a guard post up ahead.

"Piece of cake." they said. "Clear it with that shotgun you just bought." they said.

I jumped off the Jeep and pulled out my shotgun. It really was a thing of beauty, a work of art: it was ornately decorated with what looked like silver on an African or Brazilian wood with a reddish hue. The sound of it being fired was pleasant but aggressive, kind of like gangsta rap or heavy metal. It was brand new, and I decided to affectionately name it Ho Lee Schitt, after my adoptive father from China.

I sprinted over there. "YIPPIE-KI-AYE-AY â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥S" I screamed, in my best Bruce Willis voice. "It's time to â¥â¥â¥â¥ â¥â¥â¥â¥ up!"

But then, I realized the harsh reality of what was coming. I had limited ammo, and no grenades or molotovs. I had the rapt attention of about five heavily armed people who I had just threatened. The fastest means of escape I had was a small dune buggy on the other side of the shantytown. Malaria struck me almost instantly, and I heard the roar of a Jeep's engine. I felt a sharp pain overwhelming the entire left side of my body as I lost my grip on Ho Lee Schitt.

"HO LEE SCHITT! NO!" I screamed. and then I felt myself get smashed to the ground by a heavy steel chassis, and everything went black.

But not for long! One of my buddies that I met earlier just came to pick my pathetic, lumpy body off the ground and save my life.

"Ol' buddy, ol' pal!" I was able to whisper to myself with all of my energy.

Everything went black again, but only for about five seconds, and I saw my buddy, courageously fighting off my enemies with a rusty old pistol like the independent woman she was.

But then I noticed her struggling. She left my body on the ground as she had to load her last magazine into the pistol. Odds were, one of us or both of us were going to die, and I was determined that if any of us were to die, it would not be her.

So I bit the bullet and looked at my leg. It was surely broken, but there was a bullet hole in it, too. I couldn't just leave this bullet there, so I performed a brief, gory self-surgery with my trusty machete. She noticed that I was coming to, and decided to give me the gun.

"Go!" I yelled. "Go into that house over there for safety. If one of us dies, it will not be you!"

I saw as a bullet was fired into my left arm, which I noticed was also probably broken. I shoved my finger through the bullet hole and pushed the bullet out, leaving a clean hole in my arm.

I collapsed to the ground, like some fat guy in dire need of doughnuts. I realized that I was going to die of malaria-induced lead overdose if I didn't get up, so I popped my last malaria pill and stabbed a morphine syringe in my arm.

I arrogantly belted out, in my best James Brown voice, "AND I FEEL GOOD! I KNEW THAT I WOULD NOW."

Then I saw it. Ho Lee Schitt was in the hands of one of my enemies. I was furious. I ran over to the dune buggy I saw, jumped on it, and ran him over. He was crawling on the ground begging for mercy. I crouched next to him, and shot him once in each eye. Ho Lee Schitt was mine again.

I ran over to the two remaining men, murder in my eyes, and my tongue stretching out longer than Ace Frehley's. They each had a clear shot on me, and i risked getting buckshot all over my face and the "PIMP" tattoo on my licker; however, their rusty shotguns jammed, obviously because the bullets were scared of me. A quick bang here and a quick bang there and there were two less idiots in the world.

"AND I FEEL NICE! LIKE SUGAR AND SPICE!" I continued to sing. The adrenaline was coursing through my veins, and I jumped up in the air and high-fived my buddy. We stayed in the air for a full minute, like the end of some Van Halen concert on MTV or the closing credits of literally every episode of The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air. I was Born To Run, and against the better judgment of my friend, I kept rolling on that Thunder Road to the place beyond that guard post: New Jersey.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

"gr8 8/8 m8" - IGN

This game is amazing, definitely the best in the series, and I dare say that it is the best FPS of 2008 (yes, I know that Call of Duty: World at War came out in 2008. What about it?)

Posted: October 16
The first time I felt bad killing someone in Far Cry 2, it was a death I didnât see coming. Iâd seen plenty of unpredictable, often hilarious things happen as a result of my violent actions -- I once shot a driver who then rolled his truck into a zebra, over a bridge, and into a river. Moments like this get more out of hand in Far Cry 3 and Far Cry 4.

But when remembering my truly definitive Far Cry moments, and when asking myself which Far Cry game is best, I always think about Marty Alencar, the friend I murdered.

Marty was my first and best Buddy in Far Cry 2âs Africa. He was the man I rescued from a fiery plane crash. The guy who always brought me back to life when I took too many bullets, put a gun in my hand, and stood by my side until everyone around me died.

Far Cry 4âs Guns for Hire system operates on a similar idea to Far Cry 2âs Buddy System, allowing you to summon an ally instantly to fight alongside you. But theyâre nameless henchmen, expendable fodder I used to deliberately detonate landmines and send to certain death for the sake of distraction. I never cared about any of them. I used them.

Compare this to Far Cry 2, where I relied on Marty, approaching him every time I stepped out the door, knowing heâd tell me he had my back, knowing it was true. Marty was a good man, always ready with another option when a mission wasnât going to benefit me as much as it could. Yes, these âcharacter traitsâ fed into the gameplay structure and story missions of Far Cry 2, but it convinced me that Marty Alencar was more than a Buddy -- he was a friend.

Marty dragged me out of the line of fire and into the bushes when a random group of guys jumped me on the road. Stupid. You never take the road. A gunner on the back of a truck mowed me down while I fell into my own misplaced Molotov flames. Marty hands me a pistol and opens fire. I find a couple grenades, knock the truck around, and finish the job. When itâs all done, I hear Marty screaming for help. I canât see him.

By the time I find his blue smoke streaming out of the woods, heâs grunting incoherently. I kneel down, jab a regenerative needle into his stomach, and wait for him to head home. He doesnât get up. Heâs still wounded, so I put another needle in him. Nothing, but he slows down, and his eyes roll upward. One more needle. Martyâs head hits the ground, and he stops squirming.

I overdosed my best friend.

The wieght and impact moments like this have is why Far cry 2 is the real gem of the series and how Far Cry was meant to be. The pure unscripted brilliance.

Not Recommended
5.3 hrs on record
Posted: June 28
Itâs a great African driving simulator.

But reallyâ¦

I had high hopes for Far Cry 2. I saw the great reviews it got. But only 5 hours into it I had to stop playing. It was a combination of complete boredom, frustration and knowing Iâve already experienced all the game would have to offer.

Far Cry 2 is a very open world game. After the first guided mission you are free to go wherever you want, which is nice. Exceptâ¦

Here is the formula for every Far Cry 2 mission I encountered in 5 hours
+Drive to a place that has a mission available
+Drive to the waypoint on your map for that mission. Which is always far away.
+Get shot at driving through areas youâve already cleared.
+Repair your vehicle.
+Take down a random vehicle with a turret.
+Repair your vehicle.
+Complete mission.

Thatâs itâ¦thatâs how it was for 5 hours before I knew that was all the game had to offer and show me.

I might have been able to push through if the missions were close to one another. But, thereâs SO much driving in this game. I didnât mind that in itself. The fact that itâs not even enjoyable really killed it for me. I thought after clearing a checkpoint it would be good from then on outâ¦WRONG. Enemies always respawn everywhere. Which means you get in constant battles when you just want to drive through an area you already cleared. It makes me feel like Iâm not accomplishing anything and gives me no incentive to kill enemies. I just resorted to flying through the checkpoints and killing any vehicles that gave chase to me.

Far Cry 2, in my opinion, commits several cardinal sins in video games.
+Respawning enemies
+Enemies that can hit you from a mile away, consistently. Even with a shotgun?!
+Enemies that can instantly hit you each time you break from cover
+Enemies that know your exact location

Pros
+Open world style of gameplay
+Graphics
+Good shooter at its core
+Capturing the African environment and culture
+Music

Cons
+Respawning enemies
+Extremely repetitive gameplay
+Too much driving around
+Enemy AI
+Didn't feel rewarded for doing anything
+Strange run on sentences with the voice acting


4/10

Far Cry 2 really does have some good mechanics and systems it employs. But the negative things I mentioned above far outweigh the positives. I couldnât continue playing and therefore can only recommend if itâs on a big sale and youâre really curious. Otherwise, stay away.
